blocks.content: Brett Gibson grew up in California and attended the University of California, Santa Barbara, graduating with a Bachelor of Arts degree in philosophy.[1][2][3][4][5] Following his graduation, Gibson worked in a pizza restaurant while considering his career options.[1][26][28] During this period, he taught himself computer programming using online resources, which led to his first engineering position at Grand Central Communications in 2004.[1][3][28]

blocks.content: After earning a B.A. in philosophy from the University of California, Santa Barbara, Brett Gibson began his post-college career working in a pizza restaurant before teaching himself how to code using online resources.[1][2] In 2004, he secured his first software engineering role at Grand Central Communications, marking the start of a self-directed transition into technology.[1][3] Gibson’s entrepreneurial career commenced the following year with the launch of DrawHere, a browser-based drawing startup acquired by DeviantArt in 2006.[1][4][5][6][7]

He continued to found and build internet startups, notably creating Slinkset, a white-label social news platform admitted to the Y Combinator Summer 2008 batch.[1][3][8][9][10] In 2009, Slinkset was acquired by Posterous, a blogging platform where Gibson became a co-founder and senior engineer, working alongside Sachin Agarwal and Garry Tan. Posterous itself was also a Y Combinator company and was later acquired by Twitter in 2012.[1][3][9][11] Following Posterous’s shutdown, Gibson and Garry Tan co-founded Posthaven in 2013, a paid blogging platform dedicated to long-term data preservation. As technical co-founder, Gibson continued to focus on software development and platform stability for Posthaven.[1][6][12][13]

From 2014 to 2015, Gibson joined Y Combinator’s internal software team, where he was responsible for building and improving the systems that managed applications, interviews, events, and the alumni network.[3][14] In 2017, Garry Tan recruited Gibson to Initialized Capital, initially as Operating Partner for Engineering. His initial responsibilities included advising portfolio companies on engineering practices and developing Folio, Initialized’s bespoke internal deal-flow and investment-decision software, which implemented a blind-voting approach to selection.[1][15][16][17]

Gibson transitioned into an investment role, taking on responsibility for sourcing and advocating investments, and was promoted to General Partner at Initialized in August 2021.[1][18] His investment focuses include sectors such as crypto infrastructure, developer tools, artificial intelligence, machine learning, and cloud infrastructure. Gibson has led deals for companies such as Bison Trails, TRM Labs, and Talos Trading.[16][19]

In August 2022, following Garry Tan’s departure from Initialized Capital to become CEO of Y Combinator, Gibson was named Managing Partner of Initialized. He assumed responsibility for the firm’s investment strategy, while colleague Jen Wolf was appointed Managing Partner for operations.[20] Gibson is recognized as the key executive shaping the fund’s investment direction and continues to serve in this leadership role.[21] His professional background spans engineering, product, and investment leadership, with a record of early-stage technical entrepreneurship preceding his move into venture capital.[3][22]

blocks.content: Gibson resides in San Francisco, California. He is known to have several personal interests outside his professional activities. Notably, he has described himself as fond of pinball, and is a recreational pinball player who has competed in International Flipper Pinball Association (IFPA) tournaments in the United States over several years. Additionally, Gibson has alluded to his enjoyment of pizza-making, a skill and interest that predates his technology career. Musically, he has cited Kendrick Lamar as a favorite artist, specifically mentioning the song "You" as meaningful to his personal journey.
